authorize or direct that proceedings be commenced in the name of the association against any party on the terms the court directs,
require the association to produce financial statements,
order the association to compensate an aggrieved person, and
direct rectification of any record of the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association referred to in subsection (1) must file with the registrar a certified copy of an order made by the court under this section, or on appeal from it, within 14 days after the entry of that order in the court registry.
For the purposes of this section, a reference to a "member" or an "investment shareholder" must be read as including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a beneficial owner of a membership share or an investment share in the association, and
any other person who, in the discretion of the court, is a proper person to make an application under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court's power to restrain breach or require compliance

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to a matter other than compliance with section 8, a member, investment shareholder or other person the court considers a proper person to make an application under this section, and
in relation to compliance with section 8, a member, investment shareholder or association.

bcl:text: The court, on application of a complainant and on being satisfied that there is or will likely be
may make an interim or final order it considers appropriate and, without limiting the generality of that power, the court may grant an injunction

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a contravention by an association or any other person, of this Act or the regulations or of an association's memorandum or rules, or
a failure by an association to fulfill its obligations under this Act or the association's memorandum or rules,
restraining the association or any other person from continuing or committing the contravention, or
requiring the association to fulfill its obligations.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In any proceeding against a person who is a director, officer, receiver, receiver manager or liquidator of an association, if it appears to the court that the person is or may be liable in respect of negligence, default, breach of duty or breach of trust but has acted honestly and reasonably and ought fairly to be excused, the court must take into consideration all the circumstances of the case, including those connected with the person's appointment, and may relieve the person, either wholly or partly, from liability, on the terms the court considers necessary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application to the court under this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be made by motion, and
unless notice is specifically required by this Act, may be brought without notice to any other person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the court may direct that notice of an application under this Act be served on those persons the court requires.

On the application of at least 20% of the members or one or more investment shareholders holding in the aggregate at least 20% of the issued investment shares of any class of investment share, the court may appoint a person as an inspector to investigate the affairs and management of an association and any of its affiliates, and may determine the manner and extent of the investigation.

Notice of an application under this section must be given to the registrar, and, if the court makes an order appointing an inspector, the inspector must, within 7 days after the date of the order, file a certified copy of the order with the registrar.
The court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before appointing an inspector, require the applicant to give security for payment of the costs and expenses of the investigation, and
at any time,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: set the amount of the costs and expenses, and
order by whom and in what proportion they must be paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is a receiver of property of an association or who is a director, receiver manager, officer, employee, banker, auditor or agent of the association or of any of the association's affiliates must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: produce, for the examination of an inspector appointed under this section, every record, including every document, instrument and accounting record, relating to the association and any of its affiliates in the person's custody or control, and
give to the inspector every assistance in connection with the investigation that the person is reasonably able to give.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An inspector appointed under this section may examine on oath any person who is or was a receiver of property of an association, or a director, receiver manager, officer, employee, banker, auditor or agent of the association or of any of its affiliates, in relation to their affairs, management, accounts and records, and the inspector may administer the oath.
A person examined under subsection (5) must answer any question that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within the scope of the investigation, and
put to that person by the inspector.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the conclusion of an investigation under this section, the inspector must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: report to the court, and
send a copy of the report to the registrar, the association and any other persons the court or the registrar orders.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association may appoint an inspector by special resolution to investigate the affairs and management of the association and any of its affiliates, and to report in the manner and to the persons the resolution directs.
An inspector appointed under subsection (1) has the same powers as an inspector appointed by the court under section 158.

If an inspector is appointed under this section, a person who is or was a receiver of property of the association, and each director, receiver manager, officer, employee, banker, auditor and agent of the association or of any of its affiliates, must comply with section 158 (4) to (6) as if the inspector had been appointed by the court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An inspector appointed under this Part must not require a lawyer to disclose any privileged communication made to the lawyer in that capacity, except as to the name and address of the lawyer's clients.
A copy of the report of an inspector appointed under section 158 or 159, signed by the inspector, is admissible in any legal proceeding as evidence of the opinion of the inspector.

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means an omission, defect, error or irregularity that has occurred in the conduct of the business or affairs of an association as a result of which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a breach of a provision of this Act or the regulations has occurred,
there has been default in compliance with the memorandum or rules of the association,
proceedings at or in connection with any of the following have been rendered ineffective:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a meeting of members or investment shareholders;
a meeting of the directors or a committee of directors, or of an executive committee within the meaning of section 47;
any assembly purporting to be a meeting referred to in subparagraph (i) or (ii), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a resolution that is, or a record that purports to be, one of the following has been rendered ineffective:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a resolution of the members of an association referred to in

bcl:clause.bcl:text: paragraph (a) of the definition of "ordinary resolution", or
paragraph (a) of the definition of "special resolution";

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a resolution of the investment shareholders referred to in paragraph (c) of the definition of "separate resolution";
a resolution of directors passed in accordance with section 77 (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other provision of this Act, the court, either on its own motion or on the application of any interested person, may make an order to correct or cause to be corrected, to negative or to modify or cause to be modified the consequences in law of a corporate mistake or to validate any act, matter or thing rendered or alleged to have been rendered invalid by or as a result of the corporate mistake, and may give ancillary or consequential directions the court considers necessary.

The court must, before making an order under this section, consider the effect that the order might have on the association and on its directors, officers, creditors, members and investment shareholders. and on beneficial owners of membership shares or investment shares of the association.
Unless the court orders otherwise, an order made under subsection (2) does not prejudice the rights of any third party who acquired those rights

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for valuable consideration, and
without notice of the corporate mistake that is the subject of the order.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means the Civil Resolution Tribunal established under the ;
has the same meaning as in the ;
means a housing cooperative or a community service cooperative.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who may request resolution by civil resolution tribunal

bcl:text.#text: A housing or community service cooperative, or a member of a housing or community service cooperative, may make a request under section 4 of the  asking the civil resolution tribunal to resolve a dispute concerning a cooperative association claim.

bcl:text: A person, other than a person referred to in subsection (1), who claims

bcl:text.#text: may make a request under section 4 of the  asking the civil resolution tribunal to resolve a dispute concerning a cooperative association claim that relates to the person examining, taking extracts from, receiving a copy of or obtaining the record.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to be entitled, under section 130 of this Act, to examine and take extracts from a record of a housing or community service cooperative,
to be entitled, under section 132 or 142 of this Act, to receive a copy of a record of a housing or community service cooperative,
to be entitled, under section 133 of this Act, to obtain a record in relation to a housing or community service cooperative, or
to be entitled, under section 138 of this Act, to inspect a record of a housing or community service cooperative

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may make a request in accordance with subsection (1) or (2) whether or not the person has applied to the registrar for an order under section 135.1 of this Act.

bcl:text.#text: A request under section 4 of the  may not be made with respect to any matter relating to the termination of membership in a housing or community service cooperative, including under sections 34 to 39 and 171 of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:text.#text: means a person who, being entitled to do so, gives written notice of dissent when and as required by section 164;
means all of the shares in respect of which a dissenter must dissent under section 161 (3) or (4) and "dissenters' shares" has a corresponding meaning in relation to the dissenters to whom it refers;

means the value of a dissenter's shares immediately before the date of the resolution authorizing or effecting the corporate action in respect of which the dissenter dissented, excluding any appreciation or depreciation in anticipation of the corporate action unless exclusion would be inequitable, but in respect of membership shares of a community service cooperative or an association to which section 173 or 196 (2) applies, must not exceed the amount paid up on those member's membership shares.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A member of an association is entitled to dissent in respect of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a resolution to amend the association's rules to authorize the association to issue investment shares to non-members;
a resolution to amend the association's rules to divide the membership into classes;
a resolution to approve the association continuing into a jurisdiction other than British Columbia;
a resolution to dispose of the whole or substantially the whole of the undertaking;
a resolution passed under section 70 (2);
a resolution to amend the association's memorandum to become a community service cooperative.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An investment shareholder of an association is entitled to dissent in respect of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a resolution approving an amalgamation of the association with another or other associations;
a resolution to approve the association continuing into a jurisdiction other than British Columbia;
a resolution to dispose of the whole or substantially the whole of the undertaking;
a resolution passed under section 70 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A member who wishes to exercise a right of dissent must dissent in respect of all of the membership shares and investment shares that are limited to ownership only by members of the association and that are owned by the member.
An investment shareholder who wishes to exercise a right of dissent must dissent in respect of all of the investment shares in the association that are owned by the investment shareholder.
The right of a dissenter to obtain payment of the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares terminates on the occurrence of any one of the following events:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the corporate action in respect of which the dissenter dissented is abandoned or the resolution authorizing the corporate action is revoked;
a court of competent jurisdiction permanently enjoins or sets aside the corporate action in respect of which the dissenter dissented;
the notice of dissent given to the association under section 164 is withdrawn with the written consent of the association;
the amalgamation in respect of which a notice of dissent was given is not adopted by one or more of the amalgamating associations with the result that the amalgamation is not effected;
the dissenter, after giving notice of dissent, acts inconsistently with that dissent;

the dissenter consents to, or votes in favour of, the resolution to which the dissenter is dissenting, unless the vote is given solely as a proxy holder for a person whose proxy required an affirmative vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1) (e), a dissenter who makes a request to withdraw a notice of dissent, or a response to an offer made under section 165 (a), retains the right to obtain payment of the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares unless that request is accepted by the association.

If a resolution that might give rise to a notice of dissent is to be considered at a general meeting or a class meeting, the association must give notice to each of its members or investment shareholders, as the case may be, in the same manner as set out in section 147, accompanied by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the proposed resolution, and
a statement, in the prescribed form, advising members or investment shareholders, as the case may be, of their right to give and the consequences of giving a notice of dissent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notice under subsection (1) must be given at least 14 days before the date of the proposed meeting.
Any member or investment shareholder who receives a notice under subsection (1) (b) may give a notice of dissent to the association in respect of the resolution referred to in subsection (1).
A member or investment shareholder who is entitled to exercise dissent rights in respect of a resolution may do so by giving to the association written notice of dissent in respect of the resolution,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at or by the time specified by the resolution,

if the resolution that gives rise to the right of dissent does not specify a time for the giving of notice of dissent, at least 2 days before the date of the meeting at which the resolution in respect of which dissent may be exercised is to be passed, or
if the member or investment shareholder does not receive the notice required under section 163, within 21 days after learning that the resolution has been passed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after giving a notice of dissent, the dissenter must deliver to the association the dissenter's share certificates, unless the dissenter is a member of an association whose rules require in accordance with section 57 that it not issue membership share certificates.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the right of a dissenter to obtain payment of the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares terminates if the dissenter fails to comply with subsection (2).
A dissenter who has complied with subsections (1) and  (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may not vote, or exercise or assert any rights of a member or investment shareholder, as the case may be, in respect of the dissenter's shares, other than under this Part, and
until the dissenter is paid in full for the dissenter's shares, may exercise and assert all the rights of a creditor of the association.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An association that has authorized or effected a corporate action by a resolution in respect of which dissent was made must send to each member or investment shareholder who gave a notice of dissent in respect of the resolution,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a written offer by which the association offers to pay to the dissenter the amount estimated by the association to be the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares, and
an explanation, in sufficient detail to permit the dissenter to form a reasoned judgment concerning the matter, as to how the association estimated the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 167, if the dissenter accepts the offer made under section 165, the association must pay the offered amount to the dissenter promptly after its receipt of the dissenter's acceptance of the offer.

Within 50 days after the action approved by the resolution is effective or within such further period as the court may allow, an association may apply to the court to fix the reasonable value for the shares of the dissenters if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association fails to make an offer under section 165, or
a dissenter fails to accept an offer made under that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an association fails to apply to the court under subsection (2), a dissenter may apply to the court for the same purposes within a further period of 20 days or within the further period that the court may allow.
On an application under this section, the court may make any order it considers appropriate and, without limitation, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: grant judgment to a dissenter for the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares, as determined by the court, plus any interest the court considers appropriate,

fix the price and terms of the purchase and sale of the dissenter's shares, or order that the price and terms be established by arbitration, in either case having due regard for the rights of creditors,
join in the application any dissenter who has not accepted an offer under section 165 and any other person the court considers appropriate, and
make consequential orders and give directions it considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 167, if the court or an arbitrator determines the amount that is to be paid by the association to a dissenter, the association must promptly pay that amount to the dissenter.
An association must pay the amount to which a dissenter is entitled under section 166 unless there are reasonable grounds for believing that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association is unable to pay its liabilities as they become due in the ordinary course of business,

making the payments due to all dissenters who, at the time that the payment is due, have complied with their obligations under this Part, in respect of the same resolution, would render the association unable to pay its liabilities as they become due in the ordinary course of business, or
the realizable value of the association's assets would, after making the payments due to all dissenters referred to in paragraph (b) of this subsection, be less than the association's liabilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If reasonable grounds exist for believing that payment in full of the amount referred to in subsection (1) would have one or more of the results set out in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that subsection,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association is prohibited from paying the dissenter the full amount to which the dissenter is entitled,

the association must pay to the dissenter and to all other dissenters to whom payment is required as much of the amount that is payable to them as is possible without causing one or more of the circumstances set out in subsection (1) (a), (b) and (c) to occur, and that payment must be made ratably among all of those dissenters, and

the association remains obligated to pay the balance of the required amount and, as soon as the association is able to do so without causing one or more of the circumstances set out in subsection (1) (a), (b) and (c) to occur, must make that payment along with interest on the amount of that payment calculated

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: from the date that the association becomes obligated to pay that amount until the date that the amount is paid, and

bcl:text.#text: at the rate of interest that is used to calculate interest added to a pecuniary judgment under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 10 days after determining that subsection (2) applies, the association must notify each dissenter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the association is unable lawfully to pay dissenters the whole amount payable for the dissenters' shares, and
of the rights of dissenters under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (2) applies, a dissenter, by written notice delivered to the association within 30 days after receiving a notice under subsection (3), may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: withdraw the notice of dissent, in which event the association is deemed to consent to the withdrawal, or

retain status as a claimant against the association, to be paid as soon as the association is lawfully able to do so or, in liquidation, to be ranked subordinate to the rights of creditors of the association but in priority to its members and investment shareholders.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissenter entitled to return of shares and rights
bcl:section.bcl:text: The association must return to a dissenter each of the share certificates, if any, delivered under section 164 (2), and the dissenter regains the ability to exercise all of the rights and special rights or restrictions attached to the shares of that dissenter and, if applicable, all of the rights, obligations and limitations attached to that dissenter's membership, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the right of the dissenter to obtain payment of the reasonable value of the dissenter's shares terminates under section 162 or 164 (3), or
the dissenter withdraws the notice of dissent under section 167 (4) (a).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A dissenter is deemed to have disposed of all of the dissenter's right, title and interest in and to the dissenter's shares to the association and the association is deemed to have purchased those shares at the time the association pays to the dissenter the amount to which the dissenter is entitled under section 166.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division applies only to housing cooperatives.
Unless a provision in this Division conflicts with or is inconsistent with the other provisions of this Act, those other provisions also apply.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Any right of a member to possession or occupancy of residential premises that is dependent on the member's membership in a housing cooperative is terminated on the termination or other cessation of the membership.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court order of possession — application by housing cooperative

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After termination under section 171 of a person's right to possession or occupancy of residential premises, the housing cooperative in which the person was a member may apply to the court for an order of possession of the residential premises.

On an application under subsection (1), if an appeal has not been commenced under section 37 and the application relates to a termination under section 35, the court must first determine, on evidence the court considers relevant, whether the person's membership was terminated in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

If the court determines under subsection (2) that the person's membership was terminated in accordance with the principles of natural justice, the court must make an order of possession in favour of the housing cooperative.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court order of possession — application by member
bcl:section.bcl:text: A member of a housing cooperative who has a right to possession or occupancy of residential premises that is dependent on the member's membership may apply to the court for an order of possession of the residential premises.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special provisions on dissolution or winding up of a housing cooperative

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies only to a housing cooperative that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provides in its memorandum that this section applies to the housing cooperative,

on June 30, 1988, had in its memorandum or rules, or both, a provision to the effect that, on a dissolution or winding up, the property of the housing cooperative, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, must not be disposed of or distributed among the members, or

on June 30, 1988, had in its memorandum or rules, or both, a provision to the effect that, on a dissolution or winding up, the property of the housing cooperative, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, must not be disposed of or distributed among the members and, by that provision or another provision in its memorandum or rules, or both, established another manner for the disposition or distribution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a housing cooperative to which this section applies is dissolved or wound up, its property, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, must be dealt with as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if it is a housing cooperative described in subsection (1) (a) or (b), the property must be transferred to or distributed among one or more other organizations that are housing cooperatives to which this section applies;

if it is a housing cooperative described in subsection (1) (c), the property must be disposed of in accordance with the applicable provision in its memorandum or rules, or both, referred to in that paragraph.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in this section, no part of the property of a housing cooperative to which this section applies is to be paid or distributed to the members during its existence or on its dissolution or winding up.
A housing cooperative to which this section applies must not alter its memorandum or rules, or both, to amend or repeal a provision referred to in subsection (1).

A provision of the memorandum or rules of a housing cooperative to which this section applies that is inconsistent with the applicable provision referred to in subsection (1) is without effect to the extent of the inconsistency.
Nothing in this section prohibits a housing cooperative to which this section applies

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from doing anything permitted under section 9 or 66,

subject to its rules, from repaying to a member an amount not exceeding the value of contributions or improvements by the member, in addition to amounts paid by the member for shares, to the property of the housing cooperative, or
from paying money the housing cooperative owes to a member.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A housing cooperative to which this section applies must not issue

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: investment shares, or
membership shares other than membership shares with a par value.

bcl:text.#text: As an exception to subsection (1), this section does not apply to a housing cooperative that was dissolved, or for which winding up was commenced as referred to in section 293 or 297 of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 59, before June 5, 1995.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, between June 30, 1988 and June 8, 1995, a housing cooperative to which this section applies altered its memorandum or rules, or both, to amend or repeal a provision referred to in subsection (1), the amendment or repeal is void, and the memorandum or rules, or both, as applicable, are conclusively deemed to be as they were before the amendment or repeal.
The registrar must note in the filed memorandum or rules, or both, of a housing cooperative any changes that are effected by subsection (9).

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means a contract entered into by a person with an association to deliver to or sell through the association any thing caught, grown, made or produced by the person, or on the person's behalf, or in which the person has an interest, that person being one of a number of persons with whom the association has entered into contracts of a similar nature;
means a person who has entered into a cooperative marketing contract with an association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A cooperative marketing contract may set, as liquidated damages, that must not be regarded as penalties, specific sums to be paid by the producer to the association on the breach of any provision of the cooperative marketing contract in respect of the sale or delivery of any product, and may provide that the producer who breaks the producer's contract must pay all costs, expenses and fees if any action in respect of the breach is brought by the association.
In the event of a breach or threatened breach of a provision of a cooperative marketing contract by a producer in respect of the sale or delivery of any product, the association is entitled to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an injunction to restrain the producer and the producer's agents and servants from selling or delivering the product otherwise than in accordance with the contract, and
an order for specific performance of the contract by the producer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Pending the adjudication of any action brought by the association under this section, and on application, by one party only, to the court showing the breach or threatened breach, and on giving an undertaking or security approved by the court, the association is entitled to an interim injunction.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who uses or is employed on a fishing or fish packing vessel owned, chartered, hired or otherwise controlled by a person engaged in the fishing industry, if the vessel is used to catch, produce, collect or transport fish or other marine products,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not bound by a cooperative marketing contract with respect to the sale, delivery or other disposal of any fish or marine products caught, produced, collected or transported from, by or in the vessel, and

section 175 does not apply to the sale, delivery or other disposal of the fish or marine products unless the person who owns or controls the fishing vessel is, or if the fishing vessel is separately owned and controlled then, unless both persons are also bound by a cooperative marketing contract with the same cooperative association.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Termination of marketing contract after notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other provisions of this Act or any rule of law to the contrary, a producer may, before the end of any calendar year, give notice of termination of any cooperative marketing contract, to deliver, sell or otherwise deal with fish or other marine products, to which the producer is a party.

The notice referred to in subsection (1) must be in writing, and must be served on the association by forwarding the notice by prepaid mail to the association, addressed to its office or place of business.
If a notice is served in accordance with subsection (2), the marketing contract referred to in the notice terminates on December 31 following the date of service of the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement to respect cooperative marketing contract
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who has knowledge or notice of the existence of a cooperative marketing contract between a producer and an association must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: solicit, persuade or aid or abet the producer to sell or deliver any product otherwise than in accordance with the terms of the cooperative marketing contract,
receive for sale or other disposal any product of the producer delivered by the producer otherwise than in accordance with the terms of the cooperative marketing contract, or
acquire any product of the producer other than in accordance with the terms of the cooperative marketing contract.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association is a community service cooperative if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association includes, in its memorandum, a provision that the association is a community service cooperative,
the association's memorandum does not authorize the issuance of investment shares,
the purpose of the association, as set out in its memorandum under section 12 (d), is a charitable purpose or is otherwise to provide health, social, educational or other community services, and
the association is not a housing cooperative.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association must not include in its memorandum a provision that the association is a community service cooperative unless it is an association to which subsection (1) (b) to (d) applies.
A community service cooperative must not alter its memorandum to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend or repeal a provision referred to in subsection (1) (a),
authorize the issuance of investment shares, or
set out for the association a purpose other than a purpose referred to in subsection (1) (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a community service cooperative is dissolved or wound up, its property, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, must be transferred to or distributed among one or more of the following organizations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community service cooperative;

bcl:text.#text: a charitable organization registered under the  (Canada);
a society under the , other than a member-funded society as defined in section 190 of that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in this section, no part of the property of a community service cooperative is to be paid or distributed to the members during its existence or on its dissolution or winding up.
Neither this section nor a provision included in the memorandum of a community service cooperative under subsection (1) (a) prohibits the association

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to its rules, from repaying to a member amounts paid by the member for the member's membership shares, or
from paying money it owes to a member.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A community service cooperative must not issue, or have outstanding, any investment shares.

bcl:text: The registrar, having regard to
may order, on the conditions the registrar considers appropriate, that the community service cooperative is a reporting association.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of members of a community service cooperative,
the nature of its assets and liabilities,
the manner in which it is pursuing its purpose, or
any special circumstance, including the receipt by it of government funding,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may vary an order made under subsection (1) if there is a change in circumstance.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Designated Provinces and Extraprovincial Associations From Designated Provinces

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:text.#text: means a province designated by the Lieutenant Governor in Council for the purposes of this Part under section 178.4 (1);
means a person in a designated province who holds a position that is equivalent to the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may by regulation designate a province for the purposes of this Part.

Without limiting any other authority of the Lieutenant Governor in Council to make regulations under this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, in relation to extraprovincial corporations from a designated province or extraprovincial corporations from a designated province that are registered as extraprovincial associations, make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the filings that must be made by extraprovincial corporations or extraprovincial associations;

respecting registration of extraprovincial corporations as extraprovincial associations or as amalgamated extraprovincial associations and cancellation of registration of extraprovincial corporations as extraprovincial associations;
respecting liquidation and dissolution of extraprovincial corporations registered as extraprovincial associations;
setting out procedures that the registrar must follow before cancelling the registration of extraprovincial corporations as extraprovincial associations;
respecting changes to filed information that relates to extraprovincial associations;
setting out the duties of a liquidator of an extraprovincial corporation registered as an extraprovincial association;
respecting changes of name of extraprovincial corporations registered as extraprovincial associations;
respecting the appointment of or change in attorneys of extraprovincial associations;
respecting the form or manner in which the registrar may accept records, filings, applications, information, forms, notices and fees

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in matters governed under this section,
in respect of extraprovincial corporations from a designated province, and
in respect of extraprovincial corporations from a designated province that are registered as extraprovincial associations;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempting extraprovincial corporations or extraprovincial associations from a provision of this Act or from a provision of a regulation made under another section of this Act;
disapplying a provision of this Act or a provision of a regulation made under another section of this Act in respect of extraprovincial corporations or extraprovincial associations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting any other authority of the Lieutenant Governor in Council to make regulations under this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: setting out the powers and duties of the registrar in relation to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: matters governed by regulations made under this section,
extraprovincial corporations from a designated province, and
extraprovincial corporations from a designated province that are registered as extraprovincial associations;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to associations or persons or eligible organizations, respecting the form or manner in which the registrar may collect and transmit records, filings, applications, information, forms, notices and fees to or for an extraprovincial registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under subsection (2) or (3) may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require that a form be one established by the registrar or allow a form to be one established by the registrar, and
confer a discretion on, or delegate a matter to, the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is a conflict or an inconsistency between a regulation made under this section and a provision of this Act or a provision of a regulation made under another section of this Act, the regulation made under this section prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may enter into an agreement with an extraprovincial registrar in relation to associations incorporated or continued under this Act, extraprovincial corporations from the designated province and extraprovincial corporations from the designated province that are registered as extraprovincial associations, to address the following matters:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the collection by the extraprovincial registrar of records, filings, applications, forms, notices, fees or information required under this Act;
the collection by the registrar of records, filings, applications, forms, notices, fees or information required under an enactment similar to this Act;
the transmission of the matters referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) from the extraprovincial registrar to the registrar and from the registrar to the extraprovincial registrar;
the powers and duties of the registrar and the extraprovincial registrar in relation to a matter referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (e);
any related matter that the registrar determines is appropriately included in the agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2007-7-65.]

bcl:text.#text: In this Part, , in relation to an extraprovincial corporation that is or may be registered as an extraprovincial association under this Act, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the memorandum and rules of the extraprovincial corporation, or
if the extraprovincial corporation does not have a memorandum and rules, any other of the extraprovincial corporation's records that are similar in nature and effect to those records.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration under this Act of extraprovincial corporations organized on a cooperative basis

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial corporation that carries on business that can lawfully be carried on by an association under authority of this Act must not carry on business in British Columbia, after the elapse of 2 months after starting to carry on that business in British Columbia, under a name that includes the word "cooperative" or any expression, word or abbreviation that indicates or implies that the extraprovincial corporation is an association or cooperative, or is organized on a cooperative basis, unless the extraprovincial corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a name that fulfills the requirements of section 23 (1) to (3),
has provided evidence to the satisfaction of the registrar that the extraprovincial corporation is organized and operated and carries on business on a cooperative basis,
continues to be organized and operated and to carry on business on a cooperative basis, and
is registered under section 181 or under regulations made in accordance with Part 11.1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not act as an agent or representative of, or in any other capacity, for an extraprovincial corporation that is not registered as required by subsection (1).
A person who acts for an extraprovincial corporation, contrary to subsection (2), is personally liable for the debts and obligations incurred by the person as agent.

If the registration of an extraprovincial corporation as an extraprovincial association is cancelled under this Act, the extraprovincial corporation must cease carrying on business in British Columbia under a name that includes the word "cooperative" or any expression, word or abbreviation that indicates or implies that the extraprovincial corporation is an association or cooperative, or is organized on a cooperative basis.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may register an extraprovincial corporation under this section or under regulations made in accordance with Part 11.1 as an extraprovincial association if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the extraprovincial corporation has a name that fulfills the requirements of section 23 (1) to (3), and
the registrar is satisfied on the basis of the evidence provided under section 180 (1) (b) that the extraprovincial corporation is organized, operated and carries on business on a cooperative basis.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial corporation that is required to be registered under this Act must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file with the registrar a statement in a form established by the registrar, and
furnish the registrar with other information the registrar requires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The statement referred to in subsection (1) (a) must be accompanied by a copy of the charter of the extraprovincial corporation verified in a manner satisfactory to the registrar.

On an extraprovincial corporation complying with section 181.1 to the satisfaction of the registrar and paying the prescribed fees, the registrar, subject to section 181.21, must register the extraprovincial corporation and issue a certificate showing that the extraprovincial corporation is registered as an extraprovincial association under this Act.
On the registration of an extraprovincial association, the registrar must publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, notice of that registration.

Subject to this Act and the laws of British Columbia, an extraprovincial association registered under this Act may, for the purpose of carrying on business in British Columbia, exercise in British Columbia the powers contained in or permitted by the extraprovincial corporation's charter.
An extraprovincial association must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carry on any business that its charter restricts it from carrying on, or
carry on any business in a manner inconsistent with its charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association must not carry on any business that would be beyond the capacity of an association.
No act of an extraprovincial association, including any transfer of property to, or by, an extraprovincial association, is invalid merely because the act contravenes subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may refuse to register an extraprovincial corporation.
Sections 181.2 (2) and (3) and 181.21 do not apply to a federal corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Attorney to be appointed for certain purposes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association, unless under its charter its head office is in British Columbia, must have an attorney who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: resident in British Columbia, and
authorized by the association to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: accept service of process in every suit and proceeding by or against the association in British Columbia, and
receive every notice to the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The first attorney referred to in subsection (1) must be appointed by an extraprovincial association in the statement filed by it under section 181.1.
If the attorney referred to in subsection (1) resigns, is removed from office or for any other reason ceases to act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association must promptly file with the registrar 2 copies of a notice in a form established by the registrar, stating the full name and address of the new attorney appointed by it, and
the registrar must retain one copy and forward the other copy, certified as having been filed with the registrar, to the address of the previous attorney.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association may appoint more than one attorney, and in that case

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every attorney must be authorized to perform the acts mentioned in subsection (1) (b), and
the name and address of every attorney must be shown on the statement required by section 181.1, or in the notice required by subsection (3) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An attorney must in the presence of a witness sign the statement referred to in section 181.1 (1), or the notice required by subsection (3) of this section, as evidence of consent to act as attorney.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notices of change to be filed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association must promptly give notice to the registrar of any change

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the address of its head office in or out of British Columbia,
in the address of any attorney of the association in British Columbia, and
of its directors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: There must be filed with the registrar 2 copies of a notice of change in the address of the head office in British Columbia of an extraprovincial association, and the registrar must retain one copy of the notice and forward the other copy, certified as having been filed with the registrar, to the previous head office in British Columbia.

An extraprovincial association registered under this Act must file with the registrar a copy, verified in a manner satisfactory to the registrar, of any amalgamation agreement to which it is a party within one month after the date the agreement takes effect.

The registrar must issue a supplementary certificate of registration in respect of any amalgamation of an extraprovincial association and must publish a notice of it in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner.

From the date of a supplementary certificate referred to in subsection (2), the amalgamated extraprovincial association is seized of and holds and possesses all the land located in British Columbia of the amalgamating entities to the extent expressed in the amalgamation agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendments to charter to be filed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association registered under this Act must file with the registrar a copy, verified in a manner satisfactory to the registrar, of an amendment to its charter within one month after the date of the amendment.

The registrar may issue a supplementary certificate of registration in respect of any amendment to the charter of an extraprovincial association and may publish a notice of it in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner.

An extraprovincial association registered under this Act must not change its name to a name identical to that by which another corporation is incorporated or registered in British Columbia, or to a name so nearly resembling that name as, in the opinion of the registrar, is likely to confuse or mislead, or to a name of which the registrar for any other reason disapproves, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the other corporation is in the course of being dissolved and signifies its consent in the manner the registrar requires, or

bcl:text.#text: the other corporation has filed with the registrar a notice under section 197.1 (1) of this Act or section 397 (b) of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an extraprovincial association registered under this Act changes its name to a name identical to that by which another corporation has previously been incorporated or registered in British Columbia, or to a name so nearly resembling that name as, in the opinion of the registrar, is likely to confuse or mislead, the registrar may order the extraprovincial association to change its name to one that the registrar approves.
This section does not apply to a federal corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Records to be kept in British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association must keep, at its head office in British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a register of its directors that includes the following information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the full names and residential addresses of the directors;
the date on which each director was elected or appointed;
the date on which each former director ceased to hold office as a director;
the name of any office in the association held by a director, the date of the director's appointment to the office and the date on which the director ceases to hold office, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of its charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The register of directors referred to in subsection (1) (a) must include information relating to matters occurring after the extraprovincial registration of the association.
The records, documents and instruments referred to in subsection (1) (b) are those relating to matters occurring since the incorporation or amalgamation of the extraprovincial association.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maintenance of and access to records
bcl:section.bcl:text: Any person may examine and take extracts from the records mentioned in section 181.61, and sections 131, 132, 135 and 136 apply to those records.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An extraprovincial association that is not registered as required by this Act is not capable of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintaining an action, suit or other proceeding in any court in British Columbia in respect of any contract made in whole or in part in British Columbia in the course of or in connection with its business, or

bcl:text.#text: acquiring or holding land or an interest in it in British Columbia or registering any title to it under the .

bcl:text: If

and the association is subsequently restored to the register, subsection (1) and any prohibition having a similar effect formerly in force must be read and construed as if no disability under subsection (1) or under that prohibition had ever attached to the association, even if any contract was made or proceeding in respect of it was instituted, or any land or interest in it was acquired or held by the association, before the date on which the association was restored, subject to the terms of any order made by the court.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registration of an extraprovincial association is cancelled, or
an extraprovincial association has been struck off the register in accordance with any former Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a federal corporation.

bcl:text: In any prosecution, the onus of proving that an extraprovincial association
is on the defendant.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is registered,
is not required to be registered, or
has otherwise complied with this Act

bcl:division.bcl:text: Continuation of Cooperative Associations into or out of British Columbia

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: includes an Act, statute, ordinance, letters patent, certificate, declaration or other instrument or provision of law by or under which a foreign cooperative has been incorporated, amalgamated or continued, and also includes the foreign cooperative's constitution, memorandum, rules, articles, regulations or bylaws, agreement or deed of settlement;
means a corporation that has been incorporated as a cooperative association and that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2007-7-69.]
has been incorporated other than by or under an Act, or
is otherwise subject to the laws of a jurisdiction other than British Columbia;

bcl:text.#text: means, in respect of a foreign cooperative, the jurisdiction in which it was incorporated or, if it has been continued into a jurisdiction other than British Columbia, that jurisdiction.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A foreign cooperative, if it appears to the registrar to be authorized by the laws of the foreign cooperative's jurisdiction, may file with the registrar 2 copies of an instrument of continuation continuing the foreign cooperative as if it had been incorporated under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The instrument of continuation under section 183 must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the name of the foreign cooperative;
the date and jurisdiction of the incorporation of the foreign cooperative;
the full address of the registered office that the foreign cooperative will have in British Columbia;
the classes and denominations of shares authorized by the foreign cooperative;
the full names and addresses of all directors and officers of the foreign cooperative;
any other material that may be prescribed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contain a statement verifying that foreign cooperative has made the amendments referred to in subsection (2),
be executed by the foreign cooperative and verified by a signed statement of the person signing the instrument of continuation, and
be accompanied by the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the charter of the foreign cooperative;
a memorandum that complies with section 12;
rules that comply with section 13;
any other material required by the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The foreign cooperative must make the amendments to its charter that are necessary to make the memorandum and rules referred to in subsection (1) (d) conform to the laws of British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate of continuation into British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On filing the instrument of continuation of a foreign cooperative into British Columbia, the registrar must issue a certificate of continuation into British Columbia.
The registrar must publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, notice of the continuation of the foreign cooperative into British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences of continuation into British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the time that a foreign cooperative is continued into British Columbia as an association under section 185,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association becomes an association to which this Act applies and this Acts applies to the association as if it had been incorporated under this Act,
the memorandum and rules that accompanied the instrument of continuation on its filing with the registrar become the memorandum and rules of the association,
the certificate of continuation into British Columbia is deemed to be the certificate of incorporation of the association,
the property of the foreign cooperative continues to be the property of the association,
the association continues to be liable for the obligations of the foreign cooperative,
an existing cause of action, claim or liability to prosecution is unaffected,

a civil, criminal, quasi criminal, administrative or regulatory action or proceeding being prosecuted or pending by or against the foreign cooperative may be prosecuted or its prosecution may be continued, as the case may be, by or against the continued association, and
a conviction against, or ruling, order or judgment in favour of or against, the foreign cooperative may be enforced by or against the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A certificate of continuation into British Columbia is conclusive proof for the purposes of this Act and for all other purposes that the foreign cooperative has been continued under this Act as of the date and, if applicable, the time shown in the certificate of continuation.

A share of a foreign cooperative continued under this Act that was issued in compliance with the laws of the foreign cooperative's jurisdiction and with the foreign cooperative's charter is deemed to have been issued in compliance with this Act and with the provisions of the rules referred to in section 184 (1) (d) (iii).
Continuation of a foreign cooperative as an association under this section does not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deprive a member of any right or privilege that the member claims under an issued membership share,
deprive an investment shareholder of any right or privilege that the investment shareholder claims under an issued investment share,
relieve a member of any liability with respect to an issued membership share, or
relieve an investment shareholder of any liability with respect to an issued investment share.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), an association, if authorized by its members and the registrar in accordance with this section, may make an application to the appropriate official or public body of another jurisdiction, requesting that the association be continued as if it had been incorporated under the laws of that other jurisdiction.
Subsection (1) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an association that has included in its memorandum a provision described in section 196 (2),
a housing cooperative that provides in its memorandum that section 173 applies to it, or
a community service cooperative.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association must not apply under subsection (1) to be continued as a foreign cooperative under the laws of another jurisdiction unless those laws provide that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property of the association continues to be the property of the foreign cooperative,
the foreign cooperative continues to be liable for the obligations of the association,
an existing cause of action, claim or liability to prosecution is unaffected,

a civil, criminal, quasi criminal, administrative or regulatory action or proceeding being prosecuted or pending by or against the association may be prosecuted or its prosecution may be continued, as the case may be, by or against the foreign cooperative, and
a conviction against or ruling, order or judgment in favour of or against the association may be enforced by or against the foreign cooperative.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association is authorized by the members to apply for continuation into a jurisdiction other than British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the members approve the continuation by a special resolution, and

if the association has investment shares outstanding, the investment shareholders of each class of investment shares approve the continuation by separate resolutions, or if the association has outstanding shares of only a single class of investment shares, the investment shareholders of that class approve the continuation by a separate resolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association seeking an authorization under subsection (4) may submit the application to the registrar for approval, and the registrar must approve the application if the registrar is satisfied that the application is not prohibited by subsection (3).

An association is authorized by the registrar to apply for continuation into a jurisdiction other than British Columbia when, after receipt from the association of an application in a form satisfactory to the registrar, the registrar approves the application.

The authorization under subsection (5) expires 6 months after the date on which the registrar approves the application unless, within that period, the association is continued under the laws of the other jurisdiction.

bcl:section.bcl:text: At any time before an association is continued from British Columbia into another jurisdiction under the laws of the other jurisdiction, the directors of the association, if authorized by the resolutions referred to in section 187 (4), may abandon an application under section 187 without further approval of the members or investment shareholders.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association that, under this section, has been continued from British Columbia into another jurisdiction under the laws of the other jurisdiction must file with the registrar a copy of the instrument of continuation issued to it by the other jurisdiction within 60 days after the date of its issue.

On receiving a notice satisfactory to the registrar that an association has been continued from British Columbia into another jurisdiction under the laws of the other jurisdiction, the registrar, if the registrar had approved the application for continuation under section 187 (5), must file the notice.
The registrar must publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, notice of the continuation of the association from British Columbia into another jurisdiction.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When Act ceases to apply to association continued out of British Columbia
bcl:section.bcl:text: An association ceases to be an association under this Act on and after the date on which the association is continued under the laws of the other jurisdiction.

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means the associations that amalgamate and continue as an amalgamated association under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any 2 or more associations may amalgamate and continue as an amalgamated association by passing the resolutions required by subsection (3) of this section that authorize their respective directors, or some of them, to subscribe jointly to a memorandum according to the form referred to in section 11 (a), and to comply in other respects with section 11, and, for that purpose the associations may authorize alterations to name, objects and share capital as necessary.
The following resolutions are required for the purpose of subsection (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a special resolution of each of the amalgamating associations;

if any of the amalgamating associations has investment shares outstanding, a separate resolution of the investment shareholders of each class of investment shares, or if that amalgamating association has outstanding shares of only a single class of investment shares, separate resolutions of the investment shareholders of that class.

bcl:section.bcl:text: On the registrar issuing a certificate of amalgamation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each member of the amalgamating associations becomes a member of the amalgamated association until that membership is terminated in accordance with this Act and the memorandum and rules of the amalgamated association,
each investment shareholder in the amalgamating associations who has not given notice of dissent under section 164 becomes an investment shareholder in the amalgamated association,
all property and rights of each amalgamating association are transferred to and vested in the amalgamated association without any further act or deed,
the amalgamated association becomes liable for all the debts and obligations of each amalgamating association, and
the rights of creditors of each amalgamating association continue and are enforceable against the amalgamated association.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An association to which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 173 applies may not amalgamate with another association unless that section also applies to the other association,
section 178.1 applies may not amalgamate with another association unless that section also applies to the other association, and
section 196 (2) applies may not amalgamate with another association unless that section also applies to the other association.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Repealed 2007-7-73.]
Subject to section 194.11, an association may be wound up voluntarily if the association so resolves by special resolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If it is proposed to wind up an association voluntarily, the majority of the directors, before calling the general meeting at which the resolution for the winding up of the association is to be proposed, must make an affidavit declaring that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: they have made a full inquiry into the affairs of the association, and
they are of the opinion that the association will be able to pay its debts in full within the period, not exceeding 12 months from the start of the winding up, specified in the affidavit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An affidavit referred to in subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made within 5 weeks before the date on which the members pass the resolution for the voluntary winding up of the association, and
contain a statement of the assets and liabilities of the association as at the latest practicable date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A copy of the affidavit must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filed with the registrar before the meeting, and
presented to the meeting at which the resolution for the voluntary winding up of the association is to be proposed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an association is wound up in accordance with a resolution passed within 5 weeks after the making of the affidavit, but its debts are not paid or provided for in full within the period stated in the affidavit, it is presumed, until the contrary is shown, that the declarant did not have reasonable grounds for the declarant's opinion.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A voluntary winding up starts at the time of the passing of the special resolution to wind up.

An association must, at the general meeting at which the special resolution to wind up is passed, appoint one or more liquidators for the purpose of winding up the affairs and distributing the assets of the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association may be wound up by court order on the application of the association, a member, an investment shareholder, a director, a creditor, a trustee for debentureholders or a receiver manager of the association.
Before hearing an application by a creditor to wind up an association by court order, the court may require the creditor to give security for the costs of the application.
The court may order that an association be wound up

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the court thinks it just and equitable to do so, or
when an event occurs on the occurrence of which the memorandum or rules provide that the association is to be dissolved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, a reference to a "member" or an "investment shareholder" must be read as including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a beneficial owner of a membership share or an investment share in the association, and
any other person who, in the discretion of the court, is a proper person to make an application.

bcl:text: If an application for an order to wind up an association is made by a member or investment shareholder on the ground that it is just and equitable that the association be wound up, the court, if it is of the opinion that the applicant is entitled to relief either by winding up the association or under section 156, may
as the court considers appropriate.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order for winding up, or
make an order under section 156

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Start of winding up by court order
bcl:section.bcl:text: The start of a winding up by court order is the date of the order.

If the court makes an order that an association be wound up, the court, by the same or a subsequent order, must appoint one or more liquidators for the purpose of winding up the affairs and distributing the assets of the association.

bcl:text.#text: A person not qualified to become or act as a receiver or receiver manager under section 64 of the  is not qualified to become or act as a liquidator, except that, with the consent in writing of all the members, a person mentioned in section 64 (2) (e) of the  who is licensed as a trustee under the  (Canada) is qualified to become or act as a liquidator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who has been appointed a liquidator and who is not, or who ceases to be, qualified to act as a liquidator must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a voluntary winding up, promptly call a general meeting to replace the person in accordance with section 194.21 (a), or
in a winding up by court order, promptly bring the disqualification to the attention of the court and the person on whose application the liquidator was appointed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A liquidator appointed in a voluntary winding up may resign the office of liquidator.

A liquidator appointed in a voluntary winding up may be removed as liquidator by a special resolution passed at a general meeting of the members of the association, notice of which has been given to the liquidator and the creditors of the association.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Liquidator ceasing to act to file notice
bcl:section.bcl:text: A liquidator who resigns, is removed from office or, for any other reason, ceases to act must, within 7 days afterwards, file with the registrar a notice in the form established by the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filling vacancy in office of liquidator
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a vacancy in the office of liquidator occurs by death, resignation or otherwise,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a voluntary winding up, the association in general meeting may fill the vacancy, and, for that purpose, a general meeting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: may be called by any member or, if there were more liquidators than one, by any continuing liquidator, and
must be held in the manner required by the rules, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a winding up by court order, the court may fill the vacancy on application of any person mentioned in section 194.14 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The remuneration of a liquidator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a voluntary winding up, may be set by the association in general meeting, or
in a winding up by court order, must be set by the court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the remuneration referred to in subsection (1) (a) is not set within 30 days after the liquidator's appointment, or if the liquidator is dissatisfied with the amount, the liquidator may apply to the court to set or review the liquidator's remuneration, and the court may make any order it considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An act of a liquidator is valid, despite any defect in the liquidator's appointment or qualifications.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of resolution or order for winding up

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an association is being wound up,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the association, from the start of the winding up, must cease to carry on its business except so far as, in the opinion of the liquidator, is required for its beneficial winding up, but the corporate status and corporate powers and capacity of the association continue until it is dissolved,
on the appointment of the liquidator, the powers of the directors cease, except so far as the liquidator approves their continuance,
any transfer of shares made after the winding up, except a transfer made to or with the approval of the liquidator, is void, and

subject to subsection (2), the property of the association, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, including the remuneration of the liquidator, must be distributed among the members or investment shareholders according to their rights and interests in the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (d) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a housing cooperative to which section 173 applies,
a community service cooperative, or
an association to which section 196 applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing and publication of notice of appointment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A liquidator must, within 10 days after the liquidator's appointment as liquidator, file with the registrar a notice of the appointment in a form established by the registrar and, if not already filed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the winding up is a voluntary winding up, a copy of the special resolution to so wind up, or
if the winding up is by court order, a certified copy of the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A liquidator must, within 7 days after changing the liquidator's address, file with the registrar notice of the new address.

At the start of the winding up, the liquidator must publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, a notice that the association has resolved to wind up voluntarily or that the court has made an order that the association be wound up by court order, as the case may be.
A liquidator must, within 14 days after the liquidator's appointment as liquidator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mail to every person who appears to the liquidator to be a creditor of the association a notice that a meeting of the creditors of the association will be held on a date, being not less than 21 days and not more than 28 days after the appointment, at an hour and, if applicable, at a place in British Columbia specified in the notice, and
advertise notice of the meeting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, and
in a local newspaper circulating in the district where the registered office is located or where the principal place of business of the association in British Columbia was located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the meeting of creditors is an electronic meeting, the notices referred to in subsection (1) (a) and (b) must also contain instructions for attending and participating in the meeting by telephone or other communications medium.

The liquidator must present to the meeting of creditors referred to in subsection (1) a full statement of the position of the affairs of the association, including a list of the creditors of the association and the estimated amount of their claims, and the creditors are at liberty to discuss any matter arising out of the statement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the liquidator gives notice in writing by registered letter to a creditor of the association that the debt or claim of the creditor is disputed or rejected, the creditor may commence an action in respect of the debt or claim within 3 months after the notice is given, and, in default of the commencement of the action within that time, the debt or claim of the creditor is forever barred.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The liquidator of an association, subject to any restrictions or directions imposed or given by the court, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: take into the liquidator's custody or under the liquidator's control all the property and things in action to which the association is or appears to be entitled, and all the association's records, documents and instruments,
subject to this Act, use the liquidator's own discretion in realizing the assets of the association and distributing them among the creditors and members or investment shareholders,
keep proper accounting records,
keep proper minutes of proceedings at meetings and of other matters relating to the winding up,

bcl:text: cause to be stated on every invoice, order for goods and business letter,
that the association is in liquidation, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: issued by the liquidator or on the liquidator's behalf, and
on or in which the name of the association appears,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe themselves as the liquidator of the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a winding up continues for more than one year, the liquidator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: call a general meeting of the association at the end of the first year and of each succeeding year after the start of the winding up, or as soon as may be convenient,
present to the general meeting an account of the liquidator's acts and dealings and of the conduct of the winding up during the preceding year, and
file with the registrar, within 7 days after the date on which the meeting is held, a verified summary of the liquidator's receipts and payments during that year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A liquidator must comply with Part 8 in respect of the records, documents and instruments of the association.

Subject to this section, a liquidator, so far as may be necessary for the beneficial winding up of the affairs and distribution of the assets of an association, has the powers of the directors and officers, and may exercise the powers of the association that are not required by this Act to be exercised by the association in general meeting.
In a voluntary winding up, the association, by ordinary resolution, may direct that the liquidator not do certain specified things without

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of a general meeting of the association,
the written consent of certain specified members, or
the written consent of a certain specified number of members.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In any winding up, the court may impose, either generally or with respect to certain matters, restrictions on the exercise of the powers of a liquidator.

bcl:text: Until required for distribution, cash balances held by the liquidator may be invested as follows:
and any dividends or interest received from the investments form part of the assets of the association.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in an interest bearing account with any savings institution;
