bcl:text.#text: as permitted under the provisions of the  respecting the investment of trust property by a trustee,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If several liquidators are appointed, every power given to a liquidator may be exercised by the one or more of them that may be determined at the time of their appointment or subsequently, or, in the absence of any determination, by any 2 or more liquidators.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Sale of association for shares or debentures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if an association is being wound up and it is proposed to transfer or sell the whole or part of its business or property to a corporation, the liquidator of the association being wound up may, with the approval of a special resolution of that association that confers on the liquidator either a general authority or an authority in respect of a particular arrangement, in compensation or part compensation for the transfer or sale,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receive shares, debentures or other similar interests in the corporation for distribution among the members or investment shareholders of the association being wound up, or

enter into any other arrangement by which the members or investment shareholders of the association being wound up may, instead of receiving cash, shares, debentures or other similar interests, or in addition to them, participate in the profits of or receive any other benefit from the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a housing cooperative to which section 173 applies,
a community service cooperative, or
an association to which section 196 applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If any transfer, sale or arrangement in accordance with this section involves the payment, or any liability for payment, of money by the members or investment shareholders of the association being wound up, whether to that association, the liquidator or otherwise, a member or investment shareholder may, not more than 7 days after the passing of the resolution, give a notice of dissent to the liquidator, in which event Part 10 applies.

No special resolution referred to in subsection (1) is invalid for the purposes of this section merely because it is passed before or concurrently with a resolution for winding up the association or for appointing its liquidator.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If an association is being wound up, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on application by a member or director of the association, order a general meeting, class meeting or meeting of the creditors of the association to be held and conducted in the manner the court considers appropriate,

on application by any of the persons mentioned in section 194.14 (1), make an order for the audit or the inspection of the accounts, books and papers of, or in possession of, the liquidator that the court considers appropriate,
on application by the liquidator, set a time within which creditors are to prove their debts or claims or be excluded from the benefit of any distribution to be made by the liquidator,
in a voluntary winding up, appoint a liquidator on application by a member if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: there is no liquidator acting, and
it is impractical or impossible to hold a general meeting of the association for the purpose of filling the vacancy,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on cause shown by any of the persons mentioned in section 194.14 (1), remove a liquidator and fill any vacancy in the office of the liquidator,
release, on terms and conditions the court considers appropriate, a liquidator who has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: resigned,
been removed from office, or
in the liquidator's opinion, fully wound up the affairs of the association,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on application by any of the persons mentioned in section 194.14 (1), confirm, reverse or modify any act or decision of a liquidator and make any order the court considers appropriate,
if a liquidator does not faithfully perform the liquidator's duties, inquire into the matter and take the action the court considers appropriate,

bcl:text: on application by any of the persons mentioned in section 194.14 (1),
and this provision applies even if the conduct complained of is conduct for which the person may be liable to prosecution,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: examine into the conduct of any person who has taken part in the formation or promotion of the association or any person who is a past or present director, officer, receiver, receiver manager, liquidator, member or investment shareholder of the association, if it appears that the person

bcl:clause.bcl:text: has misapplied, retained or become liable or accountable for any money or property in relation to the association, or
has become liable or accountable for any breach of trust in relation to the association, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: compel the person to repay or to restore the money, or property, or any part of it, with interest at the rate the court considers appropriate, or to contribute the sum to the assets of the association by way of compensation in respect of the misapplication, retainer or breach of trust as the court considers appropriate,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order, on terms and conditions the court considers appropriate, staying the proceedings either absolutely or for a limited time, and
on application by the liquidator, give directions in relation to any matter arising under the winding up.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who is a present or former director, receiver manager, officer, employee, banker, auditor, member, investment shareholder or agent of, or receiver of property of, an association that is being wound up or of any affiliate of it must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on inquiry by the liquidator, fully and truly inform the liquidator, to the best of the person's knowledge and belief, of all the property of the association and how and to whom and for what consideration and when the association disposed of any part of it, except any part disposed of in the ordinary course of business of the association,
on request of the liquidator, deliver to the liquidator, or as the liquidator directs, all the property of the association in the custody or under the control of the person, and

on request of the liquidator, deliver to the liquidator, or as the liquidator directs, every record, including every document, instrument and accounting record, in the custody or under the control of the person and belonging to the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as the affairs of an association are fully wound up, the liquidator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare an account of the winding up, showing how it has been conducted and how the property of the association has been disposed of, and
call a final general meeting of the association for the purpose of presenting the account and giving any explanation of it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The final general meeting referred to in subsection (1) must be called by publishing notice of it in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, at least 14 days before the meeting, specifying the object, date and time and, if applicable, the place, and no other notice is necessary.
If the final general meeting is an electronic meeting, the notice must also contain instructions for attending and participating in the meeting by telephone or other communications medium.

If, within 1/2 hour after the time appointed for the final general meeting, a quorum of members is not present, the liquidator must adjourn the meeting to the same day in the next week and, if at the adjourned meeting a quorum is not present within 1/2 hour after the time appointed for the meeting, the meeting must proceed and is deemed to have been properly held.
The liquidator, not more than 7 days after the final general meeting, must file with the registrar a copy of the account and a return in a form established by the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolution on completion of winding up

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar, on receiving the copy of the account and the return referred to in section 194.33, must file them.
Three months after the filing referred to in subsection (1), the association is dissolved.

On application by the liquidator or any person mentioned in section 194.14 (1), the court may make an order deferring the date at which the dissolution of the association is to take effect for the time the court considers appropriate.
No order made under this section is effective unless a certified copy of the order is filed with the registrar before the association is dissolved under subsection (2).

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  has the same meaning as in the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a liquidator has or controls any unclaimed or undistributed assets or money of the association that have remained unclaimed or undistributed for more than 6 months after the date on which any dividend declared by the liquidator became payable, the liquidator must promptly pay or deliver the same to the administrator with a statement showing the full names and last known addresses of the persons appearing to be entitled to the assets or money and the amounts to which they appear to be respectively entitled, and the administrator must give the liquidator a receipt, which receipt is an effectual discharge to the liquidator.

bcl:text.#text: The administrator, in respect of any money or assets paid or delivered to the administrator under this section, may invest the money or realize the assets and invest the proceeds, and the money so received or realized by the administrator is deemed to be an unclaimed money deposit under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disposal of books and papers of association
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an association has been dissolved, the liquidator is responsible for the care and custody of its records, including documents, instruments and accounting records, for 2 years after the date of dissolution, but not longer.

An order of the court releasing a liquidator discharges the liquidator from all liability in respect of any act done or default made by the liquidator in the administration of the affairs of the association or otherwise in relation to the liquidator's conduct in that capacity, but that order may be revoked on proof that it was obtained by fraud or by suppression or concealment of any material fact.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of appointment and change of address

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The liquidator of an extraprovincial association registered under this Act must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 7 days after the liquidator's appointment, file with the registrar a notice of the appointment in a form established by the registrar, and
within 7 days after changing the liquidator's address, file with the registrar notice of the new address.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The liquidator of an extraprovincial association registered under this Act must promptly publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, a notice that the association is being wound up.

The liquidator of an extraprovincial association registered under this Act must, on completion of the winding up, file with the registrar a copy of the account and a return in a form established by the registrar.
The registration of an extraprovincial association is cancelled 3 months after the filing of the account and return referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolutions and cancellations of registrations by registrar

bcl:text: If
the registrar must mail to the association or extraprovincial association a letter notifying it of its failure or of the registrar's belief, and of the registrar's powers under subsection (3).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an association or an extraprovincial association has for 2 years failed to file with the registrar the annual report or any other return, notice or document required by this Act to be filed by it,
the registrar has reasonable cause to believe that an extraprovincial association has ceased to carry on business in British Columbia,
an association or an extraprovincial association has failed to pay, within 10 days after default in payment of the fine, any fine imposed on it under this Act, or
an association or an extraprovincial association has failed to comply with an order of the registrar,

bcl:text: If an association or an extraprovincial association is being wound up, and

the registrar must mail to the association a letter inquiring whether a liquidator is acting, or the association is fully wound up, or notifying the association of the failure to file returns, or of the registrar's belief and of the registrar's powers under subsection (3).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar has reasonable cause to believe that no liquidator is acting, or that the association is fully wound up, or
the returns required to be made by the liquidator have not been made for a period of 3 consecutive months,

bcl:text: If, within one month after the registrar mails the letter referred to in subsection (1) or (2), the registrar does not receive a response that

the registrar may publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, a notice that, at any time after the expiration of one month after the date of publication of the notice, unless cause is shown to the contrary, the association may be dissolved or, in the case of an extraprovincial association, its registration may be cancelled.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indicates that the failure has been or is being remedied,
notifies the registrar that the extraprovincial association continues to carry on business in British Columbia, or
is otherwise satisfactory to the registrar,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any time after one month after the date of publication of the notice referred to in subsection (3), the registrar, unless good cause to the contrary is shown to the registrar, may dissolve the association or, in the case of an extraprovincial association, cancel its registration.
A letter mailed under this section may be addressed to the association at its registered office or, in the case of an extraprovincial association, at its head office in British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council, by order, may cancel the incorporation of an association and declare it to be dissolved.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of registration of extraprovincial association

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may cancel the registration of an extraprovincial association.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may restore the registration of an extraprovincial association that has been cancelled.
This section does not apply to a federal corporation.

An association without issued investment shares may provide in its memorandum that, on the dissolution or winding up of the association, its property, after satisfaction of its liabilities and the costs, charges and expenses properly incurred in the dissolution or winding up, must be transferred to or distributed among one or more other organizations that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: associations having a similar purpose to the association being dissolved or wound up, or

bcl:text.#text: charitable organizations registered under the  (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association may provide in its memorandum that a provision described in subsection (1) is unalterable, and, if it so provides, the association must not alter its memorandum to amend or repeal that provision or the provision described in subsection (1).
Neither this section nor a provision in the association's memorandum permitted by subsection (1) or (2) prohibits the association

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from doing anything permitted under section 9 or 66,
subject to its rules, from repaying to a member amounts paid by the member for the member's membership shares, or
from paying money it owes to a member.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association that has included in its memorandum a provision described in subsection (2) must not issue any investment shares.
An association may apply to the registrar, in a form established by the registrar, to be dissolved if the association

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is authorized to do so by a special resolution,
has no assets, and
has no liabilities, or has made provision for the payment of each of the association's unpaid liabilities and has obtained the written consent to that provision for payment from each creditor

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: whose identity is known to the association, and
who has an unpaid claim against the association that exceeds the prescribed amount.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An association's application under subsection (1) must be accompanied by the association's certificate of incorporation and by an affidavit of one of the directors of the association evidencing to the satisfaction of the registrar that the association has complied with subsection (1).
If the registrar grants an association's application under this section for dissolution, the association is dissolved on the date set by the registrar.
If an extraprovincial association files with the registrar a notice that the association has ceased to carry on business in British Columbia, the registrar may cancel its registration.

The registrar must cancel the registration of an extraprovincial association if the registrar receives, from an official having a similar role to the registrar in the jurisdiction in which the extraprovincial association was incorporated, notice that the extraprovincial association has ceased to exist.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The liability of every director, officer, liquidator, member and investment shareholder of an association that is dissolved, or of an extraprovincial association that has had its registration cancelled, continues and may be enforced as if the association had not been dissolved, or the registration of the extraprovincial association had not been cancelled.

The registrar must publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, notice that an association has been dissolved or that the registration of an extraprovincial association has been cancelled, along with the date the action took place.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an association has been dissolved, or the registration of an extraprovincial association has been cancelled under this Act or any former Act, the court may, if it is satisfied that it is just that the association or extraprovincial association be restored to the register, not more than 10 years after the date of the dissolution or cancellation, on application by a liquidator, a member, an investment shareholder or a creditor of the association or extraprovincial association, or by any other interested person, make an order, subject to the conditions and on the terms the court considers appropriate, restoring the association or extraprovincial association to the register.

If an association or extraprovincial association is restored to the register under subsection (1), the association is deemed to have continued in existence, or the registration of the extraprovincial association is deemed not to have been cancelled, and proceedings may be taken as might have been taken if the association had not been dissolved or the registration of the extraprovincial association had not been cancelled.

The court may make an order under subsection (1) restoring an association or an extraprovincial association to the register for a limited period, and, after the expiration of that period, the association must promptly be dissolved, or, in the case of an extraprovincial association, its registration cancelled, by the registrar.
The court must not make an order under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless notice of the application under subsection (1) and a copy of any document filed in support of it has been sent to the registrar and the registrar has consented, and

until one week after the applicant has published notice of the application under subsection (1) in one issue of the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, and has mailed notice of that application to the last address shown as the registered office of the association or head office in British Columbia of the extraprovincial association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In an order made under section 197.4, the court may give directions and make provisions it considers appropriate for placing the association or extraprovincial association and every other person in the same position, as nearly as may be, as they would have been had the association not been dissolved or the registration of the extraprovincial association not been cancelled.

Unless the court otherwise orders, an order under subsection (1) is without prejudice to the rights of parties acquired before the date on which the association or extraprovincial association is restored to the register.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In any order made under section 197.4, the court may require that the association or extraprovincial association be restored to the register under a different name that is acceptable to the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No order made under section 197.4 is effective until a certified copy has been filed with the registrar.
The registrar must not file any order made under section 197.4 unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar receives proof to the registrar's satisfaction that the terms and conditions precedent of the order, if any, have been complied with, and
the registrar's requirements are fulfilled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After filing an order made under section 197.4, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: publish, in the Gazette or in any other prescribed manner, notice of the restoration of an association or extraprovincial association, showing the date of restoration, and
issue a certificate of restoration.

bcl:text.#text: Despite the provisions of this Act, title to, or any interest in, land that has escheated or that is deemed to have escheated to the government under section 4 of the  is not affected in any way by an order made under section 197.4 of this Act, except as provided in section 4 of the .
Sections 4 and 5 of the  do not apply to this Act or the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person commits an offence who

bcl:text: contrary to section 158 or 159,
or otherwise fails to comply with section 158 or 159,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: refuses to produce any record, including any document, instrument or accounting record,
refuses to answer any question, or
destroys or alters any record, including any document, instrument or accounting record,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fails to give information required of the person under section 158 or 159,
is an extraprovincial association and contravenes any of the provisions of this Act, or of the regulations, that apply to it,

is a director of an association and makes an affidavit under section 194.11 without having reasonable grounds for the opinion that the association will be able to pay its debts in full within the period specified in the affidavit,
acts as a liquidator and is a person who is not qualified to act as a liquidator,
is a liquidator and contravenes any provision of Part 14,
[Repealed 2007-7-74.]
contravenes section 134 or 194.32, or
contravenes section 180 (1), (2) or (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), a person who, in a record, makes or assists in making a statement required or permitted to be made by or for the purposes of this Act or the regulations commits an offence if the statement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time and in the light of the circumstances under which it is made, is false or misleading in respect of any material fact, or
omits any material fact, the omission of which makes the statement false or misleading.

bcl:text: If

who authorizes, permits or acquiesces in the commission of the offence also commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding $5 000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or to both, whether or not the corporation or the association, as the case may be, is prosecuted or convicted.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a corporation commits an offence under subsection (1), any director or officer of the corporation, or
an association commits an offence under subsection (1), any general manager, any other officer or any director of the association

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person does not commit an offence under this section if that person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not know that the statement was false or misleading, and
with the exercise of reasonable diligence, could not have known that the statement was false or misleading.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under section 199 (a), (a.1), (a.2), (a.3), (a.4), (a.5) or (a.6) or 200 (1) is liable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a corporation, to a fine of not more than $5 000, or
in the case of a person that is not a corporation, to a fine of not more than $2 000.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under section 199 (c) is liable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a corporation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on a first conviction, to a fine of not more than $10 000, and
on each subsequent conviction, to a fine of not more than $25 000, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a person who is not a corporation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on a first conviction, to a fine of not more than $5 000, and
on each subsequent conviction, to a fine of not more than $10 000.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under section 199 (d) is liable to a fine in a prescribed amount for each day that the offence continues.
A legal proceeding, conviction or penalty for an offence under this Act does not relieve a person from any other liability.

Without limiting subsection (1), if a person is convicted of an offence under this Act, the court may, in addition to any penalty or punishment the court may impose for the offence, order the person to comply with the provisions of this Act.
A person who contravenes an order under subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to the penalties or punishments provided for the offence in relation to which the order was made.
A legal proceeding for an offence under this Act may not be commenced more than 3 years after the commission of the offence.
[Repealed 2007-7-76.]

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a direction, decision, order or ruling by the registrar under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person affected by a decision under this Act may appeal it to the court.
The registrar is a party to an appeal of a decision to the court.
An appeal under subsection (2) is an appeal on the record.
For the purposes of subsection (4), the record consists of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the record of oral evidence, if any, before the registrar;
copies or originals of documentary evidence before the registrar;
other things received as evidence by the registrar;
the registrar's direction, decision, order or ruling;
the written reasons for the decision, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal under subsection (2) must be commenced not more than 30 days after the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mailing to the appellant, at the appellant's most recent address known to the registrar, of a notice of the decision to be appealed;
actual notice to the appellant of the decision to be appealed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (7), arbitration may be used to decide a dispute arising out of the affairs of an association, between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person aggrieved who has for not more than 6 months ceased to be a member, a person claiming through such an aggrieved person, a member, an investment shareholder, a person claiming through a member or an investment shareholder or a person claiming under the association's rules, and
the association or a director of the association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The decision made is binding on all parties and may be enforced on application to the court.
Unless the association's rules otherwise provide, there is no appeal from a decision made in an arbitration under this section.

bcl:text.#text: Unless the association's rules establish another method, an arbitration under this section must be conducted in accordance with the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any of the parties to a dispute described in subsection (1) may commence arbitration proceedings by giving 7 days' written notice to the other parties to the dispute.
A person is not entitled to bring proceedings under this section in respect of any dispute that is the same or substantially the same as a matter in which the person has an interest, if the matter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has been decided by order of the court under section 156,
is the subject of court proceedings under section 156, unless the court otherwise orders on the grounds of undue delay to which the applicant has not contributed,

bcl:text.#text: has been decided by the civil resolution tribunal under the , or
is a claim that is being adjudicated by the civil resolution tribunal under the .

Arbitration in respect of a dispute must not be commenced under subsection (1) once an initiating notice has been given under section 6 of the  in relation to the dispute, unless the civil resolution tribunal has notified the parties of its refusal to resolve the dispute.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not hold out the prospect of employment for wages or salary as an inducement to invest in the shares or securities of an association.
There must be paid to the registrar for the prescribed matters the prescribed fees, and the registrar must pay the fees to the Minister of Finance.

bcl:text.#text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing forms, documents, reports and other records for the purposes of this Act;
prescribing conditions for the purposes of sections 36 (2) (e) and 37 (2.1) (b) and establishing rules respecting those conditions;
respecting meetings of directors, members, investment shareholders or creditors that are partially electronic meetings or fully electronic meetings, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing requirements for notice of those meetings, and
prescribing procedures for voting at those meetings;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing circumstances in which an association must hold meetings of directors, members, investment shareholders or creditors that are fully electronic meetings, even if the association's rules provide otherwise;
defining any word or expression used but not defined in this Act;
respecting any matters necessary for more effectively bringing into operation the provisions of this Act and for obviating any transitional difficulties encountered in doing so.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:text.#text: includes a certificate, under an enactment, evidencing the continuation, as an association, as defined in this Act, of a corporation incorporated in another jurisdiction;

means an association incorporated or continued under the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 71, before the date this section comes into force, and includes an association to which section 74 or 75 of that Act applied before that date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Membership shares of pre-existing associations with one class of share
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the share capital of a pre-existing association consists of only one class of shares, the association's memorandum is deemed to be amended to provide that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the pre-existing association's shares are renamed membership shares, and
there is no maximum number of membership shares that the pre-existing association is permitted to issue.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Membership shares of pre-existing associations with 2 or more classes of shares

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the share capital of a pre-existing association consists of more than one class of shares and the members of the pre-existing association have been required to purchase the shares of only one class of shares of the pre-existing association, its memorandum is deemed to be amended to provide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that all the shares of the class of shares of the pre-existing association that members have been required to purchase are renamed membership shares,
that all the shares of the other class or classes of shares of the pre-existing association are restricted for issue to members only and are renamed as investment shares, and
that the number of membership shares, and the number of investment shares in each class, that may be issued is unlimited.

bcl:text: If a pre-existing association

the pre-existing association, by a date prescribed for the purpose of this subsection, must change its memorandum, rules or both to comply with section 12 (f) and (g) and, if applicable, change its memorandum, rules or both to comply with sections 48 and 49.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has more than one class of shares but members have not been required to purchase shares of any one of those classes of shares, or
has more than one class of shares and members have been required to purchase shares of all or more than one of those classes of shares,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of section 216 to certain pre-existing associations
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 216 applies only to a pre-existing association described in section 214 (2) and continues to apply to that a pre-existing association until it has made the changes required under section 214 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A pre-existing association described in section 214 (2) must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a full text of the special rights or restrictions attached to any class of shares is contained in or permanently attached to every share certificate representing that class of shares, or
every share certificate representing shares of a particular class of shares states that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: special rights or restrictions are attached to that class of shares, and
a free copy of the full text of the special rights or restrictions may be obtained at the registered office of the pre-existing association.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A pre-existing association must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep at its registered office a copy of the full text of the special rights or restrictions attached to any class of shares, and
provide a free copy of that text to any person who requests one.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The rules of a subsisting association or society that was incorporated under a former Act, insofar as they are not contrary to this Act, continue in force until altered or rescinded, and if any of those rules have incorporated by reference any provisions of a schedule to a former Act, the appropriate provisions of that schedule are incorporated and are part of the rules of the association.

If a subsisting association or society that was incorporated under a former Act has a nominal capital of a set amount, the part of its memorandum by whatever name called that provides for that nominal capital continues in force until the association or society passes a special resolution altering its memorandum by converting its nominal capital into a share capital consisting of a limited or unlimited number of membership shares with or without par value, as set by the resolution.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of associations incorporated before June 30, 1988

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the words "the objects for which the association is formed are" or words of similar effect are contained in the memorandum of an association incorporated before June 30, 1988, those words are deemed to be struck out and the words "the business that the association is permitted to carry on is restricted to the following:" are deemed to be substituted for them.

If the business that an association is permitted to carry on is restricted under subsection (1), the association may, however, carry on and undertake any business that may be conveniently carried on in connection with the business to which the association is restricted.
This Act, except sections 5 (4) and 222, comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

bcl:text.#text: Section 222 comes into force on the date section 445 of the , S.B.C. 1999, comes into force.
